Award.AwardTitle: SI2-SSE: Foundations for MATPOWER as an Extensible Tool for Power Systems Research and Education

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The electric power system is one of the most fundamental and critical infrastructures underlying modern society, and the economic, environmental and societal impacts of advances in its planning and operations are potentially enormous. MATPOWER is a set of open-source scientific software elements for electric power system simulation, analysis and optimization. MATPOWER is already widely used in its current form, especially for research and education. The purpose of this project is to restructure the internals of MATPOWER as well as software development platform to make it easier to customize and extend by its community of users and developers. This restructuring will serve to increase MATPOWER's future impact as a successful research tool for designing and analyzing the power systems of the future. As power grids evolve toward more sustainable, economically efficient and environmentally friendly systems, positioning MATPOWER to expand its role as a flexible research and educational tool in this arena of innovation and change has the potential for far reaching and transformative impact both nationally and globally.

MATPOWER addresses some of the most fundamental classes of problems in power systems analysis, namely the power flow (PF), optimal power flow (OPF) and related problems used to determine the steady state voltages, currents and power flows arising from the interactions between system conditions, operator control actions and the laws of physics. The aim of this work is to broaden and extend MATPOWER's reach as a research-enabling tool for tackling future power systems problems in two specific ways. The first is to develop the project infrastructure needed to transition to and sustain a community-driven, collaborative development paradigm. The second is to redesign the core MATOWER software around a general modular architecture that will enable more flexible user customization and facilitate significant user contributions, while retaining and enhancing the simplicity that makes it attractive in education. Specifically, the new architecture will greatly simplify the process of adding arbitrary new device models, such as three-winding transformers, voltage dependent loads, flexible AC transmission system (FACTS) devices and more sophisticated models of HVDC lines. It will also facilitate the inclusion of additional controls, such as remote voltage regulation, switched shunts and transformer and phase shifter tap changing. Finally, it will serve as the basis to expand MATPOWER to handle three-phase, unbalanced network modeling, as required for many low-voltage distribution systems, opening the door for use in many additional current and emerging research areas.

POR.DRECONTENT:
This project set out to broaden and extend MATPOWER's reach as a research-enabling tool for tackling future power systems problems by (1) developing the project infrastructure needed to transition to and sustain a community-driven, collaborative development paradigm, and (2) redesigning the core MATOWER software to enable more flexible user customization and facilitate significant user contributions.

The first goal was accomplished by launching an all new MATPOWER web site at https://matpower.org, moving all MATPOWER development to public repositories on GitHub, and creating new mailing lists for the MATPOWER community. The new MATPOWER Development organization on GitHub hosts more than a dozen new repositories for MATPOWER-related development, each with its issue tracker for submitting contributions, reporting bugs, and asking questions. As a result, MATPOWER has already benefited from numerous and significant community contributed and collaboratively developed enhancements that were included in subsequent MATPOWER releases.

This collaboration resulted in the inclusion of three new power flow (PF) and optimal power flow (OPF) formulations, with documentation in two new MATPOWER Technical Notes (3 and 4), as well as several new power flow algorithms, including some tailored specifically for distribution systems. Support was also added for users to define their own general nonlinear OPF constraints and costs, extending the user customization capabilities. In addition, the OPF soft-limit capabilities were greatly expanded. These and many more enhancements were included in two new major releases of MATPOWER, namely 6.0 and 7.0, which have been downloaded more than 120,000 times.

In light of the new PF and OPF formulations, the planned redesign of the core software for a unified network element model was expanded and further generalized to include these additional formulations. This network model design, called MP-Element, was developed and documented in the new MATPOWER Technical Note 5, "MP-Element: A Unified MATPOWER Element Model". This model allows network elements to be defined in terms of a few simple parameters which define the port injections as functions of the port voltages and element state variables. The aggregation of these elements to create the network equations and their derivatives is all handled automatically, allowing for easy addition of arbitrary new element types.

An initial version of the code to implement the MP-Element model, including all of the functions and derivatives elaborated in Tech Note 5, was completed and is available in its own GitHub repository. It enables power flow and optimal power flow problems to be solved for various problem formulations and solvers using the new generalized network model based on MP-Element. This architecture enables new user customization and the modeling of new device types and it lays the groundwork for multi-phase modeling for distribution systems. It is planned for inclusion, along with other significant enhancements, in the next major MATPOWER release.
